creditline: Lent by the Frederick R. Weisman Art Musem, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis
description: stoneware plate without rim and slightly tapered foot; blue green glaze with brown patterning of radiating lines from center at interior
text: Made by the Japanese potter Hamada Shoji in the early 1950s, these five plates exhibit five different patterns yet unified by similar materials: clay, slips, pigments and oxides. In 1920, Hamada met the English potter Bernard Leach (1887-1979), and together they set up the Leach Pottery in St. Ives, Cornwall, England. While in England Hamada collected English ceramics decorated with slip (or thin clay) trailing, a form of decoration popular from the 16th century to the present . Hamada transformed the traditional English patterns into Japanese expressions.
title: Plate, one of five
